section.title: Some of these data were published as a data report:
section.para: Caine, N., and L. Buchanan. 1987. Streamflow data from the Green Lakes Valley, 1981-1986. University of Colorado Long-Term Ecological Research Data Report 87/4. 34 pp.

abstract.para: This is a summary of discharges from the Martinelli Basin and is based on stage records from the outlet channel 30 m below the road at the foot of the basin.

section.title: Niwot LTER Data Policy
section.para:
The following acknowledgment should accompany any publication or citation of these data:
Logistical support and/or data were provided by the NSF-supported Niwot Ridge (NWT) Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) project and the University of Colorado (CU) Mountain Research Station (MRS).
The user of NWT LTER data agrees to provide proper acknowledgment with each usage of the data. Citation of the name(s) of the investigator(s) responsible for the data set, in addition to the generic statement above, constitutes proper acknowledgment. Author(s) (including NWT investigators) of published material that makes use of previously unpublished NWT data agree to provide the NWT data manager with a PDF of that material as soon as it becomes available. The user of NWT data agrees not to resell or redistribute shared data.

section.title: Disclaimer
section.para: The NSF-supported NWT LTER project shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein, nor assumes liability for misuse, manipulation or distribution of the data. These data are not legal documents and are not intended to be used as such. The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The user of these data should be aware that, while efforts have been taken to ensure that these data are of the highest quality, there is no guarantee of perfection for the data contained herein and the possibility of errors exists. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data appropriately and in a manner consistent with the limitations of data in general and these data in particular. Users assume responsibility to determine the usability of the dataset. NWT LTER gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data. It is strongly recommended that these data be directly acquired from the NWT LTER server and not indirectly through other sources that may have changed the data in some way. Although these data have been processed successfully on computer systems at CU, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the utility of the data on other systems for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Study site was located at the outlet channel 30 m below the road at the foot of the Martinelli Basin. Original data consisting of charts and hourly stage readings are stored at Research Laboratory #3.

description.para: The documentation section of this file was developed from the NWT LTER Data Directory (Symphony files DDABSTRA.WR1, DDDOCUME.WR1, DDMASTER.WR1, DDVARIAB.WR1; last updated 16 December 1991) by Susan Kindig and Rick Ingersoll in early November 1992. Additional information for the documentation section, as well as the header and data sections were supplied by Nel Caine on 8 January 1993.[RCI, 12 January 1993] Minor modifications were made to the documentation sections based on comments supplied by Nel Caine on 25 January 1993.[RCI, 25 January 1993] This file was put under sccs control on 30 March 1993. See the appropriate history file for additional log information.[RCI 30 March 1993] Data for 1993 were provided by NC on 22 November 1993 and appended to the data section on 24 November 1993.[RCI 24 November 1993] Data for 1994 and 1995 were provided by NC and were appended to the data section on 13 February 1996.[MAH 13 February 1996] The reference to Caine 1995 was added to the citations section on 6 May 1996.[MAH 6 May 1996] Data for 1996 provided by NC were appended to the data section on 26 August 1997.[MAH 26 August 1997] The investigator contact information was updated on 9 June 1999.[MAH 9 June 1999] Data for 1997 and 1998 were appended to the data section on 29 September 2000.[MAH 26 September 2000] Data for 1999 and 2000 were appended to the data section on 28 June 2001.[TMA 28 June 2001] Data for 2001 were appended to the data section on 29 January 2002.[TMA 29 January 2002] Data for 2002 were appended to the data section on 27 January 2003.[TMA 27 January 2003] Data for 2003 were appended.[TMA 19 July 2004] Data for 2004 were appended to the data section.[TMA 01 February 2004] Data for 2005 and 2006 were appended to the data section.[TMA 8 March 2007] The comments section was revised to include specific information for each year starting in 1997. All data were replaced with comma delimited columns and data for 2007 to 2009 were added. The variable list was updated to reflect inclusion of date and comment columns along with discharge volume.[HCH 22 October 2010] Updated title and keywords and appended comments and data for 2010.[HCH 1 December 2011] Data for 1 October 2010 through 30 September 2012 were appended; title, keywords, methods, and data formats were edited.[HCH 20 June 2013]

address.deliveryPoint: Institute of Arctic and Alpine Research (INSTAAR)
Institute of Arctic and Alpine Research (INSTAAR)

description.para: Citations:

Caine, T.N. 1982. Water and sediment flows in the Green Lakes Valley, Colorado Front Range. Pp 13-22 In Halfpenny, J.C.(ed.). Ecological studies in the Colorado alpine. University of Colorado, Institute of Arctic and Alpine Research, Occasional Paper 37. 147 pp.
Caine, N. 1984. Elevational contrasts in contemporary geomorphic activity in the Colorado Front Range. Studia Geomorphologica Carpatho-Balcanica 18: 5-31.

Caine, N. 1985. Sediment movement and storage on alpine slopes in the Colorado Rocky Mountains. Pp 115-137 In Abrahams, A.D.(ed.). Hillslope processes. Binghamton Symposium in Geomorphology, International Series 16. Boston: Allen and Unwin.
Sarantitis, B. 1986. Temporal variation in the runoff hydrograph of an alpine snowfield. M.A. thesis, University of Colorado, Boulder. 158 pp.
Caine, N. 1989. Diurnal variations in the inorganic solute content of water draining from an alpine snowpatch. Catena 16: 153-162.
Caine, N. 1989. Hydrograph separation in a small alpine basin based on inorganic solute concentrations. Journal of Hydrology 112: 89-101.
Caine, N., and F.J. Swanson. 1989. Geomorphic coupling of hillslope and channel systems in two small mountain basins. Zeitschrift fur Geomorphologie 33(2): 189-203.
Caine, N., and E.M. Thurman. 1990. Temporal and spatial variations in the solute content of an alpine stream, Colorado Front Range. Geomorphology 4: 44-72.

Reddy, M.M., and N. Caine. 1990. A small alpine basin budget: Front Range, Colorado. Pp 370-385 In Poppoff, I.G., C.R. Goldman, S.L. Loeb, and L.B. Leopold. Subalpine processes and water quality. International Mountain Watershed Symposium, Tahoe Resource Conservation District, South Lake Tahoe, CA, 610 pp.
Caine, N. 1992. Modulation of the diurnal streamflow response by the seasonal snowcover of an alpine basin. Journal of Hydrology 137: 245-260.

Caine, N. 1992. Spatial patterns of geochemical denudation in a Colorado alpine environment. Pp 63-88 In Dixon, J.C., and A.D. Abrahams (eds.). Periglacial geomorphology. Chichester: John Wiley and Sons, Ltd.
Caine, N. 1992. Sediment transfer on the floor of the Martinelli snowpatch, Colorado Front Range, U.S.A. Geografiska Annaler 74A (2-3): 133-144.
Caine, N. 1995. Snowpack influences on geomorphic processes in Green Lakes Valley, Colorado Front Range. Geographical Journal 161: 55-68.
Methods:

Each day starts at 12:00 MST. Flows (Q) for 1982-1985 were derived from stage records using the following formula: Q = 0.00172 * Stage ^ 2.808. Flows (Q) for 1986 were derived from stage records using the following formulae: Q = 0.00075 * Stage ^ 2.649 (for stage > 4.14) and Q = 0.00692 * Stage ^ 1.087 (for stage LT or = 4.14). Flows (Q) for 1987-1995 were derived from stage records using the following formula: Q = 0.022 * Stage ^ 2.6793. Flows were initially calculated in cfs and later converted to m3/sec. Stage was measured from the top of a metal rod in the left bank of the channel at control section of 30 m downstream of culvert at base of Martinelli. Daily flows were estimated by trapezoidal integration of 25 hourly flows. Data for 26-28 May 1990 were estimated because of a snow-clogged channel. Data for 6-10 May 1994 were estimated from occasional field observations and not a continuous logger record. The pressure transducer cell was reset about 6 cm lower in the channel on 8 June 1995.
1997 to 2012: Stages may be converted to discharges by the rating for this station: Q(l/s) = 0.01514 * Stage^2.872.

1997: Recorded water levels should be corrected as follows to give stage values: Stage (cm) = Level(cm) - corrxn. May 12 to June 30: correction starts at 14.97 cm, changes by 0.112 cm/day, June 30 to Aug 7: correction 9.454 cm (constant), Aug 7 to Oct 9: correction changes by -0.043 cm/day. Record starts 05/12/97 12:30 MST; record ends 10/09/97 12:15 MST.

1998: Recorded water levels should be corrected as follows to give stage values: Stage (cm) = Level(cm) - corrxn, where corrxn = changes over the season: at 05/18/98 corrxn = 16.47 cm, to 05/29/98 corrxn changes by -0.12235 cm/day, to 06/27/98 -0.10664 cm/day, to 07/26/98 -0.01986 cm/day, to 09/24/98 +0.08077 cm/day. Record starts 04/30/97 11:50 MST. Record until 05/26/98 shows intermittent flows. Record ends 09/24/98 when channel dry and logger removed.

1999: Recorded water levels should be corrected as follows to give stage values: Stage (cm) = Level(cm) - corrxn, where corrxn changes over the season from 20/04/99 to 25/05/99, corrxn = 17.5 cm from 25/05/99 to 26/06/99, corrxn changes by -0.162 cm/day from 26/06/99 to 29/07/99, corrxn = 12.346 cm from 29/07/99 to 14/09/99, corrxn changes by +0.079 cm/day. Record starts 20/04/99 11:55 MST and ends 14/09/99. Record until 03/06/99 is intermittently affected by snow and ice in channel; that between 19/05 and 26/05 should be ignored. Record ends when channel dry and logger removed (13:00 MST 14/09/99).

2000: Omnidata Easylogger 900 installed 16/05/00 1300 MST; removed 14/09/00 12:55 MST. Recorded water levels should be corrected as follows to give stage values: Stage (cm) = Level(cm) - corrxn, where corrxn = 13.1485 - 0.234 * Day + 0.00156 * Day^2 (R^2 = 0.895, N = 39) in which Day count starts at 01/05/00 12:00 MST. Record starts 20/04/00 10:45 MST and ends 14/09/00 12:55 MST.

2001: Omnidata Easylogger 900 installed 22/05/01 11:10 MST; removed 6/09/01 15:00 MST. Recorded water levels should be corrected as follows to give stage values: Stage (cm) = Level*1.1841 - 11.029 (cm) from 22/05/01 to 31/05/01, Stage (cm) = Level*0.8223 - 3.9255 (cm) from 31/05/01 to 19/06/01. Linear interpolation of adjacent calibrations 19-21/06/01. Stage (cm) = Level * 1.06 - 6.09 from 21/06/01 to 6/09/01. Record starts 3/05/01 11:10 MST and ends 6/09/01 15:00 MST.

2002: Omnidata Easylogger 900 installed 27/04/02 10:25 MST; removed 20/08/02 11:35 MST. Recorded water levels should be corrected as follows to give stage values: Stage (cm) = Level*1.2534 - 6.1057 (cm) r2 = 0.9454; N = 34.

2003: Omnidata Easylogger 900 installed 02/05/03 11:55 MST, failed 08/07/03 00:05 MST, removed 23/07/03 08:35 MST, Unidata Starlogger #2426 installed 24/07/03 07:55 MST; removed 25/09/03 13:30 MST. Recorded water levels should be corrected as follows to give stage values for Omnidata Easylogger 900: Stage (cm) = Level*1.117 - 7.61 (cm), r2 = 0.993; N = 64. Recorded water levels should be corrected as follows to give stage values for Unidata Starlogger: Stage (cm) = Level*1.039 - 12.57 (cm), r2 = 0.993; N = 12.

2004: Unidata Starlogger #2426 installed 01/04/04 11:30 MST; removed 02/07/04 08:45 MST. #2420 installed 02/07/04 08:45 MST; removed 02/09/04 13:15 MST. Recorded water levels should be corrected as follows to give stage values: Stage (cm) = Level*0.5812 - 10.931 r2 = 0.9751; N = 47.

2005: Omnidata Easylogger-900 installed 04/05/05 12:30 MST; removed 08/09/05 13:45 MST. Logged water levels should be corrected to stage values by: Stage (cm) = Level*1.042 - 8.13 r2 = 0.980; N = 52 (04/05/05 to 01/09/05).

2006: Omnidata Easylogger-900 installed 05/05/06 12:30 MST; removed 19/09/06 07:45 MST. Record missing from 22:40 MST 18/06 to 09:00 MST 26/06 and from 08:15 MST 25/07 to 09:00 MST 27/07 due to logger failure. Logged water levels should be corrected to stage values by: Stage (cm) = Level*1.0018 - 7.3695 (16/05/06 to 31/08/06), r2 = 0.9913; N = 48.

2007 to 2009: Field measurements of water level (WL) are taken by reference to the top of rebar on the left bank of the channel (the other rebar, closer to the center of the channel, is the support for the stilling well). Stage (S) is then defined as S = 44.4 - WL cm. Since the stilling well is installed and removed each season, the height of the pressure transducer below this reference level varies and needs to be recalibrated every season.

2007: Omnidata Easylogger-900 installed 01/05/07 12:40 MST; removed 18/09/07 13:40 MST. Because of logger failure, the following records are missing: from 23:10 MST 3 July to 08:20 MST 25 July, from 08:10 MST 21 Aug to 08:00 MST 23 Aug, from 14:40 MST 23 Aug to 08:50 MST 4 Sep. Water temperature record starts 22 May. Logged water levels should be corrected to stage values by: Stage (cm) = Level*1.0882 - 7.691 (24/05/07 to 13/09/07), r2 = 0.9916; N = 67.
2008: CR21x record started 14/05/08 11:50 MST; ended 7/10/08 08:00 MST. Logged water levels should be corrected to stage values by Stage (cm) = LVL(CR21x)*6.5787 - 6.8298 (r2 = 0.988; N = 66).

2009: CR21x record started 27/05/09 11:20 MST; ended 8/10/09 08:50 MST. Data are comma-delimited and recorded in columns: Col 21 contains the average LVL for the 10 minute interval. No flow was recorded after 11/09/09. Logged water levels should be corrected to stage values by: Stage (cm) = LVL(CR21x)*6.581 - 5.029 (r2 = 0.9915; N = 60).

2010: CR21x record started 20/05/10 12:15 MST; ended 24/09/10 09:40 MST. Data are comma-delimited and recorded in columns: Col 21 contains the average LVL for the 10 minute interval. No flow was recorded after 19:40 MST 1 September 2010. Logged water levels should be corrected to stage values by: Stage (cm) = LVL(CR21x)* 6.761 - 4.372 (r2 = 0.989; N = 59) The apparently high flows of 23/05/10 17:40 MST are probably due to blocking of the channel by snow and ice. They have little effect on the estimated total flow for the day.

2011: Field measurements of water level (LVL) are taken by reference to the top of rebar on the left bank of the channel (the other rebar, closer to the center of the channel, is the support for the stilling well). Stage (S) is then defined as S = 44.4 - LVL cm. Since the stilling well is installed and removed each season, the height of the pressure transducer below this reference level varies and needs to be recalibrated every season. For 2011, the calibration record is available in file MAR-CAL.xls. CR21x record: 2011-final-mar.rpt Started 7/07/11 11:00 MST Ended 2/10/11 10:30 MST Data are comma-delimited and recorded in columns: Col 21 contains the average LVL for the 10 minute interval. Flows were less than 1.0 L/s at the end of this record. The record from July 7 to 14 is questionable because of disturbance and equipment failure. The best estimates of stage for this interval appear to be: Stage (cm) = LVL â€“ 4.1 to 11/7 05:30 MST then Stage (cm) = LVL + 11.7 to 14/7 06:50 MST. After 15/7/11 13:20, logged water levels should be corrected to stage values by Stage (cm) = LVL(CR21x)*11.094 â€“ 5.232 (r2 = 0.998; N= 40)

2012: Field measurements of water level (LVL) are taken by reference to the top of rebar on the left bank of the channel (the other rebar, closer to the center of the channel, is the support for the stilling well). Stage (S) is then defined as S = 44.4 - WL cm. Since the stilling well is installed and removed each season, the height of the pressure transducer below this reference level varies and needs to be recalibrated every season. The CR1000 stream flow records for 2012 are available in Mar-12.xls Started 15/05/12 13:00 MST Ended 22/08/12 12:20 MST The channel was dry after 9/08/12. Logged water levels (LVL) have been corrected to stage values by Stage (cm) = LVL*10.76 â€“ 4.96 (r2 = 0.954; N = 48)
